Bandai }} {{refimprove|date=November 2018}} '''''Digimon''''' ({{lang|ja|デジモン}} ''Dejimon'', branded as '''''Digimon: Digital Monsters''''', stylized as '''''DIGIMON'''''), short for "Digital Monsters" ({{lang|ja|デジタルモンスター}} ''Dejitaru Monsutā''), is a [[Japan]]ese [[media franchise]] encompassing [[digital pet|virtual pet]] toys, [[anime]], [[manga]], [[video game]]s, [[film]]s and a [[trading card game]]. The franchise focuses on Digimon creatures, which are monsters living in a "[[Virtual world|Digital World]]", a [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universe]] that originated from Earth's various communication networks. The franchise was first created in 1997 as a [[Digital Monster (virtual pet)|series of virtual pets]], akin to—and influenced in style by—the contemporary [[Tamagotchi]] or nano [[Giga Pet]] toys. The creatures were first designed to look cute and iconic even on the devices' small screens; later developments had them created with a harder-edged style influenced by American [[comics]]. The franchise gained momentum with its first anime incarnation, ''[[Digimon Adventure]]'', and an early video game, ''[[Digimon World]]'', both released in 1999. Several seasons of the anime and films based on them have aired, and [[List of Digimon video games|the video game series]] has expanded into genres such as [[role-playing video game|role-playing]], [[racing game|racing]], [[fighting game|fighting]], and [[massively multiplayer online role-playing game|MMORPGs]]. Other media forms have also been released. ==Conception and creation== {{see also|Digital Monster (virtual pet)}} [[File:Digimon Mini.jpg|thumb|left|''Virtual pet'' model distributed on the Japanese market by [[Bandai]],{{citar web|language=english|url=http://www.tamatalk.com/pixelmood/digimon.htm|publicado=Tamatalk|autor=Pixelmood|title=Pixelmood - ''Digimon''|acessodata=22 de março de 2014}} that allowed the popularization of Digimon in [[Japan]]. It sold {{formatnum:13 million}} units in Japan and {{formatnum:1 million}} overseas, up until March 2004.{{citar web|language=english|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-05-25/new-digimon-for-2005|title=New ''Digimon'' for 2005|data=25 de maio de 2004|publicado=[[Anime News Network]]|acessodata=23 de março de 2014}}]] In the year 1996 came the [[Tamagotchi]], created by Akihiro Yokoi, Aki Maita and Takeichi Hongo, which was one of the inspirations for the first release of the franchise,{{citar web|url=http://www.manga-news.com/index.php/report/Digimon|title=Dossier (''Digimon'') — première page (Introduction)|autor=Takato e GlassHeart|data=21 de março de 2014|accessdate=April 9, 2014|publicado=Manga News|language=french}}{{citar web|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/culture/cinema/cinema-cinq-choses-a-savoir-sur-mamoru-hosoda_1150320.html?xtmc=digimon&xtcr=1|title=Cinq choses à savoir sur Mamoru Hosoda|autor=Thierry Chèze|publicado=[[L'Express]]|acessodata=11 de abril de 2014|citação=[...] un film dérivé de la saga ''Digimon Adventure'', sorte d'ancêtre des Tamagotchi.|language=french}} a device marketed in June 1997{{citar web|language=English|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/radica-games-limited-announces-manufacturing-agreement-for-new-innovative-digimon-product-77323082.html|title=Radica Games Limited Announces Manufacturing Agreement For New Innovative ''Digimon'' Product|publicado=PR Newswire|acessodata=29 de março de 2014}} with the name [[Digital Monster (virtual pet)|Digimon]],{{citar web|language=English|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/cyber/week/010198digimon.html|title=From Virtual Pet to Virtual Pit Bull: Fighting Cyber Toys|publicado=[[The New York Times]]|autor=Matt Richtel|accessdate=March 22, 2014}} a short for ''Digital Monster''.{{citar web|language=English|url=http://www.beyondhollywood.com/dvd-review-digimon-adventure-volume-2/|title=DVD Review: ''Digimon Adventure'' – Volume 2|data=March 28, 2013|autor=Dedpool|publicado=BeyondHollywood.com|accessdate=March 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140401163818/http://www.beyondhollywood.com/dvd-review-digimon-adventure-volume-2/|archivedate=April 1, 2014|df=}}{{citar periódico|language=english|journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|title=''Pokémon'', G-Boy Lead Parade of Toys at Fair|page=60|volume=112|number=13|date=March 2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sg4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=digimon+themes&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=2lFRU-WdFayT0QWAkYHwDw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwATge#v=onepage&q=digimon&f=false|accessdate=April 18, 2014}} Aiming at the male audience and created by [[Akiyoshi Hongo]] (a pseudonym that refers to the creators of ''Tamagotchi''), this device shows to players a [[virtual pet]] composed entirely of data and designed to play and fight.{{citar web|language=English|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2000/07/06/digimon-world|publicado=[[IGN]]|title=''Digimon World''. We promise not to say the word ''Pokemon'' at all in this entire review.|autor=David Zdyrko|data=5 de julho de 2000|accessdate=March 23, 2014}}{{citar web|url=http://www.liberation.fr/vous/1997/12/10/le-nouveau-tamagotchi-sera-sexueune-gamme-pour-assurer-la-rente-du-fabricant_224494|language=French|title=Le nouveau Tamagotchi sera sexué. Une gamme pour assurer la rente du fabricant.|data=10 de dezembro de 1997|autor=Tiphaine Clotault|publicado=[[Libération]]|accessdate=April 11, 2014}} In February 1998, the ''DigiMon'' fighting game, compatible with [[Windows 95]] and developed by Rapture Technologies, Inc., was announced.{{citar web|language=english|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Bandai+Digital+Entertainment+%27Ready+To+Rumble%27+in+June+with...-a020310291|title=Bandai Digital Entertainment Ready To Rumble in June with ''DigiMon'' CD-ROM|publicado=The Free Library|autor=Bandai Digital Entertainment Corp.|data=17 de fevereiro de 1998|acessodata=15 de abril de 2014}} The [[one-shot (comics)|one-shot]] [[manga]] ''[[C'mon Digimon]]'', designed by Tenya Yabuno, was published in the Japanese magazine [[V-Jump]] by [[Shueisha]] in 1997.{{citar web|language=Czech|url=http://digitalnimonstra.cz/cmon.php|title=Digimon C'mon|publicado=digitalnimonstra.cz|acessodata=22 de março de 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413124400/http://digitalnimonstra.cz/cmon.php|archivedate=2014-04-13|df=}}{{citar web|url=http://digimonfrance.wordpress.com/reprenons-du-debut/|title=Reprenons au début|publicado=Digimon France|acessodata=7 de novembro de 2010}} A second generation of ''virtual pets'' was marketed six months after the launch of the first, followed by a third in 1998.{{citar web|língua=english|url=http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art45160.asp|título=Digimon|autor=Lesley Aeschliman|publicado=Bella Online|acessodata=9 de maio de 2014}} Each player starts with a baby-level digital creature that has a limited number of attacks and transformations{{citar web|língua=english|url=http://www.virtualpet.com/vp/farm/digimon/digimon.htm|título=''DigiMon'' Virtual Pet Page|publicado=virtualpet.com|acessodata=24 de junho de 2010}} and to make the creature stronger by training and nourishing the creature; when the player is successful in a workout, the Digimon becomes strong, when the player fails, the Digimon becomes weak. Two devices can be connected, allowing two players to battle with their respective creatures, an innovation at the time, however, the battle is only possible from the moment the creature is in the child level or bigger. Playgrounds and subways were where the majority of users of the apparatus were concentrated; The virtual pet was banned in some Asian schools by being considered by parents and teachers as very noisy and violent.{{harvnb|Wolf|2008|p=218}} The first Digimon were created by Japanese designer Kenji Watanabe, influenced by American [[comics]], which were beginning to gain popularity in Japan, and as such began to make his characters look stronger and "cool." Other types of Digimon, which until the year 2000 totaled 279,{{citar web|língua=english|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/may/14/sarahryle.theobserver|título=Digital pests invade Britain|autor=Sarah Ryle|data=14 de maio de 2000|publicado=[[The Guardian]]|acessodata=15 de abril de 2014}}{{citar web|língua=english|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/DIGIMON%27S+COMING%3b+New+monster+toys+may+KO+Pokemon.-a062079625|título=''Digimon''{{'}}s coming; New monster toys may KO ''Pokemon''|publicado=The Free Library|autor=Ruki Sayid|obra=The Mirror|data=15 de maio de 2000|acessodata=15 de abril de 2014}} came from extensive discussions and collaborations between the Bandai company members.{{citar web|língua=Japanese|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201307/05035910.html|título=''『デジモンワールド リ：デジタイズ デコード』'' イラストレーターインタビュー！|site=[[Famitsu]]|data=5 de julho de 2013|acessodata=12 de fevereiro de 2014}} There are currently over 1300 Digimon. ==Eponymous creatures== Digimon hatch from types of eggs which are called {{nihongo|Digi-Eggs|デジタマ|Dejitama}}. In the English iterations of the franchise there is another type of [[Digi-Eggs|Digi-Egg]] that can be used to digivolve, or transform, Digimon. This second type of Digi-Egg is called a {{nihongo|Digimental|デジメンタル|Dejimentaru}} in [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. They age via a process called "Digivolution" which changes their appearance and increases their powers. The effect of Digivolution, however, is not permanent in the partner Digimon of the main characters in the anime, and Digimon who have digivolved will most of the time revert to their previous form after a battle or if they are too weak to continue. Some Digimon act feral. Most, however, are capable of [[intelligence]] and human speech. They are able to digivolve by the use of Digivices that their human partners have. A further level has since been used in the video games, even higher than Mega, known as ''Ultra'' in the dub. ==Anime== {{See also|List of Digimon episodes and movies}} ===Television series=== The ''Digimon'' [[anime]] series was produced by [[Toei Animation]] and Bandai of Japan. Beginning in 1999, the franchise was given an anime as the first of the ''Digimon'' [[Film|movies]] aired in [[theaters]] in Japan. Originally, the ''Digimon Adventure'' movie was supposed to be a short film, but after the storyboard was finished, a request for ''Digimon'' becoming a children's television show was made, which later became the basis for ''[[Digimon Adventure]]''. Several more series would follow, most of them with their own tie-in movies. The series was dubbed for release in Western markets, with the first four series under the title ''Digimon: Digital Monsters''. # ''[[Digimon Adventure|Digimon Adventure/Digimon: Digital Monsters (Season 1)]]'' (1999) # ''[[Digimon Adventure 02|Digimon Adventure 02/Digimon: Digital Monsters (Season 2)]]'' (2000) # ''[[Digimon Tamers|Digimon Tamers/Digimon: Digital Monsters (Season 3)]]'' (2001) # ''[[Digimon Frontier|Digimon Frontier/Digimon: Digital Monsters (Season 4)]]'' (2002) # ''[[Digimon Data Squad|Digimon Savers/Digimon Data Squad]]'' (2006) # ''[[Digimon Fusion|Digimon Xros Wars/Digimon Fusion]]'' (2010){{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-04-02/new-digital-monsters/digimon-tv-anime-listed |title=New Digital Monsters/Digimon TV Anime Listed |publisher=Anime News Network |accessdate=2012-08-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-04-02/new-digital-monsters/Digimon-tv-anime-listed|title=New Digital Monsters/Digimon Anime TV Listed|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=2010-04-02|accessdate=2010-04-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-04-05/new-digital-monsters/Digimon-tv-anime-image-posted|title=New Digital Monsters/Digimon TV Anime's Image Posted|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=2010-04-05|accessdate=2010-04-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-08-17/digimon-xros-wars-anime-to-get-2nd-year-this-october |title=Digimon Xros Wars Anime to Get 2nd Year This October - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2011-08-17 |accessdate=2012-08-15}} # ''[[Digimon Universe: App Monsters]]'' (2016){{cite web|title=Digimon Universe: Appli Monsters cross-media project officially announced|url=http://gematsu.com/2016/05/digimon-universe-appli-monsters-cross-media-project-officially-announced|website=Gematsu|accessdate=20 May 2016}} ===Films=== {{Main|List of Digimon films|Digimon: The Movie}} Several ''Digimon'' featurette films were released in Japan, with some of them seasonal tie-ins for their respective television series. In addition to the, ''[[Digimon: The Movie]]'', an American film featuring ''[[Digimon Adventure#Films|Digimon Adventure]]'', ''[[Digimon Adventure#Films|Digimon Adventure: Children's War Game!]]'', ''[[Digimon Adventure 02#Films|Digimon Adventure 02: Part 1: Digimon Hurricane Touchdown!!/Part 2: Supreme Evolution!! The Golden Digimentals]]'', was released in the United States and Canada by [[Fox Kids]] through [[20th Century Fox]] on October 6, 2000. # ''[[Digimon Adventure#Films|Digimon Adventure]]'' (1999) (released as ''[[Digimon: The Movie]]'' in Western markets) # ''[[Digimon Adventure#Films|Digimon Adventure: Children's War Game!]]'' (2000) (released as ''[[Digimon: The Movie]]'' in Western markets) # ''[[Digimon Adventure 02#Films|Digimon Adventure 02: Part 1: Digimon Hurricane Touchdown!!/Part 2: Supreme Evolution!! The Golden Digimentals]]'' (2000) (released as ''[[Digimon: The Movie]]'' in Western markets) # ''[[Digimon Adventure 02#Films|Digimon Adventure 02: Revenge of Diaboromon]] (2001) # ''[[Digimon Tamers#Films|Digimon Tamers: Battle of Adventurers]]'' (2001) # ''[[Digimon Tamers#Films|Digimon Tamers: Runaway Locomon]]'' (2002) # ''[[Digimon Frontier#Film|Digimon Frontier: Island of Lost Digimon]]'' (2002) # ''[[Digital Monster X-Evolution]]'' (2004) # ''[[Digimon Data Squad|Digimon Savers: Ultimate Power! Activate Burst Mode!!]]'' (2006) # ''[[Digimon Adventure#Films|Digimon Adventure 3D: Digimon Grand Prix!]]'' (2009) # ''[[Digimon Adventure tri.|Digimon Adventure tri. Chapter 1: Reunion]]'' (2015) # ''[[Digimon Adventure tri.|Digimon Adventure tri. Chapter 2: Determination]]'' (2016) # ''[[Digimon Adventure tri.|Digimon Adventure tri. Chapter 3: Confession]]'' (2016) # ''[[Digimon Adventure tri.|Digimon Adventure tri. Chapter 4: Loss]]'' (2017) # ''[[Digimon Adventure tri.|Digimon Adventure tri. Chapter 5: Coexistence]]'' (2017) # ''[[Digimon Adventure tri.|Digimon Adventure tri. Chapter 6: Future]]'' (2018) # ''Digimon Adventure: The Movie'' (2019){{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2018/05/05-1/new-digimon-project-announced-final-tri-chapters-hit-crunchyroll|title=New "Digimon" Project Announced, Final "tri." Chapters Hit Crunchyroll|website=Crunchyroll|first=Joseph|last=Luster|date=May 5, 2018|accessdate=May 7, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-07-29/digimon-gets-new-film-project-with-original-anime-staff-aged-characters/.134830|title=Digimon Gets New Film Project With Original Anime's Staff, Aged Characters|website=Anime News Network|first=Egan|last=Loo|date=July 29, 2018|accessdate=July 29, 2018}} ===Distribution and localization=== In the United States, the series premiered in August 1999 on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company]]. It was dubbed by [[Saban Entertainment]] (later [[Sensation Animation]]), and was initially broadcast through [[Fox Kids]]. The first four series were collectively retitled ''Digimon: Digital Monsters''.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxkids.com/tvshows/digimon/episode1.html|title=Digimon: Digital Monsters Episode Guide|work=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Family Properties]]|accessdate=2018-11-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20010615125822/http://www.foxkids.com:80/tvshows/digimon/episode1.html|archivedate=2001-06-15}} Some scenes from the original version were modified or omitted in order to comply with Fox's [[standards and practices]]. The show also featured more jokes and added dialogue, along with a completely different musical score. As a cross-promotional stunt, 2001 and 2002 saw ''Digi-Bowl'' specials co-produced with [[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]; ''NFL on Fox'' commentator [[Terry Bradshaw]] provided interstitial segments in-between episodes as if the episodes were actually a football game.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxkids.com/tvshows/digimon/digibowl/|title=Digimon: Digital Monsters: Digibowl 2002|work=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Family Properties]]|accessdate=2018-11-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20020123021428/http://www.foxkids.com:80/tvshows/digimon/digibowl/|archivedate=2002-01-23}} After [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] acquired Saban during ''[[Digimon Tamers|Digimon: Digital Monsters (Season 3)]]'', the first three series moved to the [[cable network]] [[Freeform (TV channel)|ABC Family]], while the fourth (''Frontier'') premiered on [[UPN]] due to a deal between Disney and UPN.{{cite book|title=Television Cartoon Shows: An Illustrated Encyclopedia, 1949 Through 2003, Volume 1|last1=Erickson|first1=Hal|authorlink1=Hal Erickson (author)|year=2005|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=|isbn=978-0786420995 |page=249}} [[UPN]] aired the show until late August 2003, when they severed their ties to Disney. ''Frontier'' aired on ABC Family concurrently, and reran (alongside the first three seasons) on that channel and [[Toon Disney]] (for the latter under the [[Jetix]] branding) for several years after. ''[[Digimon Data Squad]]'' also had a brief run on Toon Disney/Jetix and successor [[Disney XD]]. Toei Animation has however released an official subtitled version of ''[[Digimon Xros Wars]]''. [[Funimation Entertainment]] has online streaming rights to subtitled versions of ''[[Digimon Adventure 02]]'' and ''[[Digimon Tamers]]''. In September 2012, [[Saban Brands]] announced it had re-acquired the ''Digimon'' franchise.{{cite news|last=Crowe|first=Deborah|title=Saban Brands Acquires Digimon Anime Brand|url=http://www.labusinessjournal.com/news/2012/sep/25/saban-brands-acquires-digimon-anime-brand/|accessdate=September 26, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Business Journal|date=September 25, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Saban Brands Acquires Digimon Anime Franchise|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-09-25/saban-brands-acquires-digimon-anime-franchise|accessdate=September 26, 2012|newspaper=AnimeNewsNetwork|date=September 25, 2012}}{{cite news|author=Sarah|title=Saban Brands Acquires Digimon Brand|url=http://www.bsckids.com/2012/09/saban-brands-acquires-digimon-brand/|accessdate=September 26, 2012|newspaper=BSCKids|date=September 25, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928234026/http://www.bsckids.com/2012/09/saban-brands-acquires-digimon-brand/|archivedate=September 28, 2012|df=}} In February 2013, Saban acquired ''[[Digimon Fusion]]'' for broadcast on [[Nickelodeon]] in the United States starting September 7, 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.c21media.net/archives/100265 |title=Nickelodeon dives into Digimon | News |publisher=C21Media |accessdate=2013-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416084142/http://www.c21media.net/archives/100265 |archivedate=2013-04-16 |df= }} After three episodes, the show was moved to [[Nicktoons (TV channel)|Nicktoons]] starting October 13, 2013. ''[[Digimon Adventure]]'' and its two sequels, ''[[Digimon Adventure 02]]'' and ''[[Digimon Tamers]]'', were added to the [[Netflix]] Instant Streaming service in 2013 and 2014 with Japanese audio and English subtitles. [[Crunchyroll]] began streaming the English-subtitled version of ''[[Digimon Fusion]]'' outside Japan in November 2011. The English-localized version of its first season became available on Netflix starting September 13, 2014, followed by the second season on March 8, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-11-02/crunchyroll-to-stream-digimon-xros-wars-anime|title=Crunchyroll to Stream Digimon Xros Wars Anime|work=Anime News Network|date=November 2, 2011}} After Crunchyroll acquired streaming rights to the dubbed versions and Funimation acquired rights to the subtitled versions, the dubbed versions of ''Adventure'', ''Adventure 02'', and ''Tamers'' were briefly removed from Netflix. In Canada, the English versions were broadcast on [[YTV (TV channel)|YTV]], but only the first 26 episodes of ''Digimon Fusion'' were shown. The dubbed version of ''Data Squad'' aired on [[Family Channel (Canadian TV network)|Family Channel]]. In the United Kingdom, ''Digimon: Digital Monsters'' first aired in the UK on subscription cable/satellite channel [[Disney XD (UK and Ireland)|Fox Kids]] but gained most popularity on terrestrial channel [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s children's slot [[CITV]] from 2001-2002, which broadcast ''Adventure'', ''Adventure 02'' and a small amount of ''Tamers'' airing during after school hours. The entirety of ''Tamers'' aired on cable/satellite channel [[Disney XD (UK and Ireland)|Fox Kids]] from 2002–04. ''[[Digimon Frontier]]'' was originally announced on Jetix but was later dropped. The series eventually saw a release on October 29, 2018.https://mailchi.mp/30f437a59d09/aw-slate. From 2011, ''[[Digimon Data Squad]]'' (the fifth series/season) airs in the UK on [[Kix!]] (the show's sole provider). According to Fox Kids's (2000–03) and Kix's (2010-) [[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board|BARB]] Television ratings, ''Adventure'', ''Adventure 02'' & ''Tamers'' have been the most popular series'/seasons in the United Kingdom and was consistently in the weekly top 10 broadcasts for both channels for new episodes.{{cite web|title=Viewing Data Top 10s|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-10?|publisher=BARB (Broadcasters' Audience Research Board)|accessdate=16 January 2013}} Broadcast rights and merchandising sub-licensing rights for Digimon Fusion in the UK have been acquired by [[ITV Studios#ITV Studios Global Entertainment|ITV Studios Global Entertainment]], Digimon Fusion has aired since Spring 2014 on Digital Terrestrial Channel, [[CITV]].{{cite web|last=Clancy|first=Michelle|title=ITV to broadcast Digimon Fusion anime in 2014|url=http://www.rapidtvnews.com/index.php/2013101730346/itv-to-broadcast-digimon-fusion-anime-in-2014.html|publisher=Rapid TV News|accessdate=22 October 2013}}{{cite web|last=Dickson|first=Jeremy|title=ITV licenses Digimon Fusion|url=http://kidscreen.com/2013/10/18/itv-licenses-digimon-fusion/|publisher=Kidsscreen|accessdate=22 October 2013}} ==Manga== Digimon first appeared in [[narrative]] form in the [[One shot (comic)|one-shot]] manga ''[[C'mon Digimon]]'', released in the summer of 1997. ''C'mon Digimon'' spawned the popular ''[[Digimon Adventure V-Tamer 01]]'' manga, written by Hiroshi Izawa, which began serialization on November 21, 1998. # ''[[Digimon Adventure V-Tamer 01]]'' # ''[[Digimon Chronicle]]'' # ''[[Digimon Next]]'' # ''[[Digimon Xros Wars (manga)|Digimon Xros Wars]]'' # ''[[Digimon World Re:Digitize]]'' # ''[[Digimon World Re:Digitize|Digimon World Re:Digitize Decode]]'' # ''[[Digimon Story: Cyber Sleuth]]'' # ''[[Digimon Story: Cyber Sleuth - Hacker's Memory]]'' ===Yuen Wong Yu manhua=== A Chinese [[manhua]] was written and drawn by [[Yuen Wong Yu]] (余 遠鍠 ''Yu Yuen-wong''), who based its storyline on the television series. This adaptation covers ''Digimon Adventure'' in five volumes, ''Digimon Adventure 02'' in two, ''Digimon Tamers'' in four, and ''Digimon Frontier'' in three. The original stories are heavily abridged, though on rare occasions events play out differently from the anime. The Chinese language version was published by [[Rightman Publishing|Rightman Publishing Ltd.]] in Hong Kong. Yu also wrote ''[[D-Cyber]]''. Two English versions were also released. The first one was published by [[Chuang Yi]] in Singapore. The second one, which was adapted by [[Lianne Sentar]],{{cite web|url=http://www.liannesentar.com/works/ |title=Lianne Sentar's Other Published Works/Works List |publisher=Liannesentar.com |date=2011-10-23 |accessdate=2012-08-19}} was released by [[TOKYOPOP]] in [[North America]].
The three volumes for ''Digimon Frontier'' have been released by Chuang Yi in English. These have not been released by TOKYOPOP in North America or Europe. However, the Chuang Yi releases of ''Digimon Frontier'' were distributed by [[Madman Entertainment]] in Australia. ===Dark Horse=== {{main|Digimon: Digital Monsters (comics)}} [[Dark Horse Comics]] published American-style Digimon [[comic book]]s, adapting the first thirteen episodes of the English [[dubbing (filmmaking)|dub]] of ''Digimon Adventure'' in 2001. The story was written by Daniel Horn and Ryan Hill, and illustrated by Daniel Horn and Cara L. Niece.{{cite book | last = Horn | first = Daniel |author2=Ryan Hill | others = illustrated by Daniel Horn, Cara L. Niece | title = Digimon: Digital Monsters | year = 2001 | publisher = Dark Horse Comics | isbn = 1-56971-516-5 }} ===Panini=== The Italian publishing company, [[Panini Comics|Panini]], approached Digimon in different ways in different countries. While Germany created their own adaptations of episodes, the United Kingdom (UK) reprinted the Dark Horse titles, then translated some of the German adaptations of ''Adventure 02'' episodes. Eventually the UK comics were given their own original stories, which appeared in both the UK's official ''Digimon Magazine'' and the official UK Fox Kids companion magazine, ''Wickid''. These original stories only roughly followed the [[Continuity (fiction)|continuity]] of ''Adventure 02''. When the comic switched to the ''Tamers'' series the storylines adhered to continuity more strictly; sometimes it would expand on subject matter not covered by the original Japanese anime (such as [[Mitsuo Yamaki]]'s past) or the English adaptations of the television shows and movies (such as Ryo's story or the movies that remained undubbed until 2005). In a money saving venture, the original stories were later removed from ''Digimon Magazine'', which returned to printing translated German adaptations of ''Tamers'' episodes. Eventually, both magazines were cancelled. ==Video games== {{main|List of Digimon video games}} [[File:DigimonWorld2Battle.JPG|thumb|left|The player battles with three Digimon: Rosemon, [[List of Digimon Adventure characters#Agumon|WarGreymon]], and [[Agumon|SkullGreymon]]. The opponent's Digimon are Ninjamon, Centarumon, and SandYanmamon. Battling is an integral concept of the ''Digimon'' video game series and media franchise.]] The Digimon series has a large number of video games which usually have their own independent storylines with a few sometimes tying into the stories of the anime series or manga series. The games consists of a number of genres including [[life simulation game|life simulation]], [[adventure game|adventure]], video [[card game]], [[strategy video game|strategy]] and [[racing video game|racing]] games, though they are mainly [[action role-playing game]]s. The games released in North America are: ''[[Digimon World]]'', ''[[Digimon World 2]]'', ''[[Digimon World 3]]'', ''[[Digimon World 4]]'', ''[[Digimon Digital Card Battle]]'', ''[[Digimon Rumble Arena]]'', ''[[Digimon Rumble Arena 2]]'', ''[[Digimon Battle Spirit]]'', ''[[Digimon Battle Spirit 2]]'', ''[[Digimon Racing]]'', ''[[Digimon World DS]]'', ''[[Digimon World Data Squad]]'', ''[[Digimon World Dawn and Dusk]]'', ''[[Digimon World Championship]]'', and ''[[Digimon Masters]]''. In late 2009, Bandai created a webpage in Japanese showing a new game to be released in 2010 called ''[[Digimon Story: Lost Evolution]]'', which uses the same [[game engine|engine]] as their predecessors ''[[Digimon World DS]]'' and ''[[Digimon World Dawn and Dusk]]'' and was released on July 1, 2010. In February 2010, a website for the online multiplayer game, ''[[Digimon Battle Online]]'', was launched, showing it to be based primarily in the world of the Tamers saga and its characters.{{cite web|url=http://digimonbattle.wemade.net/main/main.asp |title=Digimon Battle- The Journey Begins. To the Digital World |publisher=Digimonbattle.wemade.net |accessdate=2012-08-15}} On September 22, 2011, online game publisher [[Joymax]] announced the release of an [[MMORPG]] game called ''[[Digimon Masters]]'', which was developed by the Korean publisher [[Digitalic|DIGITALIC]].{{cite web|url=http://my.mmosite.com/db0f8c32475df80ffc5efceb8939447c/blog/ritem/48fec1a38a4f6162b0b3379b3775c8f1.html |title=Digimon Masters OBT Sept 27th - iMMOsite get your gaming life recorded |publisher=my.mmosite.com |date=2011-09-22 |accessdate=2012-08-15}} [[File:Digimon RPG korea booth.jpg|thumb|150px|A presentation at a ''[[Digimon RPG]]'' booth in South Korea.|alt=Inside a large, brightly lit convention center room with white walls is positioned a promotional display booth for a video game. A saleswoman clad in a blue shirt and skirt and a red bowtie motions towards several illustrations on the booth, explaining their implications. The illustrations are anime-styled and depict several outlandish and brightly colored creatures. Three men in dark jackets watch the demonstration.]] In 2011, Bandai posted a countdown on a teaser site. Once the countdown was finished, it revealed a reboot of the Digimon World series titled ''[[Digimon World Re:Digitize]]''.{{cite news|last1=Romano|first1=Sal|title=Digimon World Re: Digitize a "return to origins"|url=http://gematsu.com/2011/07/digimon-world-re-digitize-a-return-to-origins|accessdate=7 August 2014|agency=Gematsu}} An enhanced version of the game released on [[Nintendo 3DS]] as ''Digimon World Re:Digitize Decode'' in 2013.{{cite news|last1=Romano|first1=Sal|title=Digimon World Re: Digitize Decode announced for 3DS|url=http://gematsu.com/2013/02/digimon-world-re-digitize-decode-announced-for-3ds|accessdate=7 August 2014|agency=Gematsu}} A new fighting game for [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] was revealed in the summer of 2014, named ''[[Digimon All-Star Rumble]]''. It was released in North America, Europe and Australia in November of the same year.{{cite news|title=DIGIVOLVE WITH BANDAI NAMCO GAMES EUROPE’S DIGIMON ALL-STAR RUMBLE IN EUROPE AND AUSTRALASIA THIS FALL|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/222503/DIGIVOLVE_WITH_BANDAI_NAMCO_GAMES_EUROPErsquoS_DIGIMONALLSTAR_RUMBLE_IN_EUROPE_AND_AUSTRALASIA_THIS_FALL.php|agency=Gamasutra}} ''[[Digimon Story: Cyber Sleuth]]'', a role-playing game in the ''Digimon Story'' sub-series, was released in 2015 for [[PlayStation Vita]] and [[PlayStation 4]] in Japan.{{cite news|last1=Romano|first1=Sal|title=First look at Digimon Story: Cyber Sleuth|url=http://gematsu.com/2013/12/first-look-digimon-story-cyber-sleuth|accessdate=7 August 2014}} It has also been released with English subtitles in North America and the rest of the world in 2016. ==Card game== The Digimon Collectible Card Game is a card game based on Digimon, first introduced in Japan in 1997 and published by Bandai. The third season (''[[Digimon Tamers]]'') utilized this aspect of the franchise by making the card game an integral part of the season. |cited_for = |cited_as = |provider = |theme_music_composer = |endtheme = }} '''''Dirty John''''' is an investigative journalism [[podcast]] hosted by journalist Christopher Goffard and created by ''[[Wondery]]'' and ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. The first two chapters were launched on October 2, 2017, with the following four chapters being released over the following days. The podcast was downloaded over 10 million times within 6 weeks of release.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://junkee.com/dirty-john-australia-tour/136046 |title= The Creator Of True Crime Podcast 'Dirty John' Is Coming To Australia |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref>
==Title== The title "Dirty John" came from one of John Meehan's nicknames given to him by his classmates during his time at the [[University of Dayton]]. Other nicknames from this time included Filthy John or just Filthy. The exact nexus of these nicknames was never divulged during the podcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/projects/la-me-dirty-john-filthy/#nt=outfit46 |title= Dirty John Part 3: Filthy - Los Angeles Times |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref>
==Synopsis== ''Dirty John'' is a [[true crime]] story focusing on the life and exploits of John Meehan. ''[[L.A. Times]]'' journalist Christopher Goffard first heard of Meehan when he learned that the police were investigating a possible murder in [[Newport Beach]]. Upon investigating, Goffard discovered a bizarre web of deceit and abuse.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/features/dirty-john-inside-hit-la-times-true-crime-podcast-w509773 |title= 'Dirty John': Inside Hit 'L.A. Times' Podcast |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref>
The main focus of the story is Meehan's relationship with businesswoman Debra Newell, whom he met via an [[Online dating service|Internet dating]] site, as well as her immediate and extended family. The podcast deals with themes of abuse and manipulation, as well as the behaviours of those being abused.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/oct/13/dirty-john-your-chilling-new-true-obsession-podcasts-of-the-week |title= Dirty John, your chilling new true crime obsession – podcasts of the week |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|newspaper= The Guardian |date= 2017-10-13 |last1= Verdier |first1= Hannah |last2= Slaney |first2= Rowan }}</ref>
Meehan himself was killed by Newell's youngest daughter Terra, who acted in self-defense when he tried to kill her on the rooftop parking lot of her apartment building on August 20, 2016. He was hospitalized and died on the 24th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/socal/daily-pilot/news/tn-dpt-me-stabbing-20160825-story.html|title=Man dies after being stabbed by woman he assaulted with knife, police say|first=Hannah|last=Fry|date=|website=latimes.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref> The story was covered by ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' on January 12, 2018, and included interviews with Goffard.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ew.com/tv/2018/01/11/dateline-nbc-dirty-john-episode-clip/|title=See Terra Newell describe her showdown with 'Dirty John' Meehan in exclusive 'Dateline NBC' clip|author=|date=|website=ew.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/dateline/coercive-control-potential-factor-dirty-john-case-psychological-abuse-n837361|title=‘Coercive control’ potential factor in ‘Dirty John’ case of psychological abuse|author=|date=|website=nbcnews.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.org/details/KNTV_20180113_060000_Dateline_NBC|title=Dateline NBC : KNTV : January 12, 2018 10:00pm-11:01pm PST|author=|date=13 January 2018|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2018|via=Internet Archive}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dayton.com/news/local/former-dayton-woman-talk-about-marriage-dirty-john-dateline/tvPMd3uVFi47hFe2oNa1JL/|title=Former Dayton woman to talk about marriage to ‘Dirty John’ on Dateline|author=|date=|website=dayton.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g-3t6vI8Xwo|title=Dirty John - Christopher Goffard speaks about his story - Dirty John Podcast|first=|last=Podcasts Dirty John by Wondery|date=21 January 2018|publisher=|accessdate=14 November 2018|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVqPWWoFyalOCIwjROCK8yg|title=Podcasts Dirty John by Wondery|author=|date=|website=YouTube|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref>
==Persons involved== * Christopher Goffard - The host, a [[Pulitzer Prize]]-nominated journalist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181114101749/https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:tC3QzgeBRZcJ:https://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-year/2007|title=2007 Pulitzer Prize Winners & Finalists|author=|date=14 November 2018|website=The Pulitzer Prizes|via=archive.org|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181114101755/https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:XiObXdKHNYgJ:https://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-year/2014|title=2014 Pulitzer Prize Winners & Finalists|author=|date=14 November 2018|website=The Pulitzer Prizes|via=archive.org|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref> * John Meehan - The titular "Dirty John.” * Debra Newell - A successful businesswoman looking for love online. * Jacquelyn Newell - Debra's older daughter. * Terra Newell - Debra's youngest daughter. * Cash - Terra's dog, a miniature Australian Shepherd. * Shad Vickers - Debra's nephew, the son of her late sister Cindi. * John Dzialo - Attorney. * Tonia Sells - John's first wife.

Times - Wondery - 'Dirty John' Canadian iTunes Chart Performance |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref> and the UK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itunescharts.net/uk/artists/podcast/la-times-wondery/podcasts/dirty-john/ |title= L.A. Times - Wondery - 'Dirty John' British iTunes Chart Performance |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref> and was downloaded over 5 million times in 3 weeks.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/radio/podcasts/dirty-john-true-story-behind-hit-podcast-changing-queasy-relationship/ |title= Dirty John: the hit podcast changing our queasy relationship with true crime |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|newspaper= The Telegraph |date= 2017-10-23 |last1= Saunders |first1= Tristram Fane }}</ref> ''Dirty John'' would have continued success having been downloaded over 10 million times within 6 weeks of release,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://junkee.com/dirty-john-australia-tour/136046 |title= The Creator Of True Crime Podcast 'Dirty John' Is Coming To Australia |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|date= 2017-11-21 }}</ref> and as of November 23, 2017 is 6th most downloaded podcasts on iTunes America.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.itunescharts.net/us/charts/podcasts/2017/11/22 |title=Podcasts Top Entries - Wednesday, 22nd |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref>
Critical reception was also positive, with the [[NME]] calling it "the best true crime podcast since [[Serial (podcast)|''Serial'']]",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-blogs/dirty-john-podcast-2151314 |title=Liked 'Serial'? Try 'Dirty John', your new true crime podcast fix |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|date=2017-10-18 }}</ref> whilst [[The Guardian]] listed ''Dirty John'' as their podcast pick of the week.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/oct/13/dirty-john-your-chilling-new-true-obsession-podcasts-of-the-week |title=Dirty John, your chilling new true crime obsession – podcasts of the week |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|newspaper=The Guardian |date=2017-10-13 |last1=Verdier |first1=Hannah |last2=Slaney |first2=Rowan }}</ref> ''Dirty John'' also received positive reviews from [[Mashable]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2017/10/10/dirty-john-podcast/#62Pl3pPDFiqW |title=The insane true story of 'Dirty John' is your next podcast obsession |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English}}</ref> [[The New Yorker]],<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/podcast-dept/dirty-john-journalism-as-noir-entertainment |title="Dirty John": Journalism as Noir Entertainment |journal=The New Yorker |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|date=2017-10-19 }}</ref> [[Rolling Stone]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/features/dirty-john-inside-hit-la-times-true-crime-podcast-w509773 |title= 'Dirty John': Inside Hit 'L.A. [[New York (magazine)|Vulture.com]] meanwhile praised the story as "stunning" but questioned the necessity of using a podcast as a way to share the story.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/10/dirty-john-podcast-review.html |title=Dirty John Is a Stunning Story, But Why Is It a Podcast? |accessdate=November 23, 2017 |language=English|date=2017-10-18 }}</ref>

It was created, produced, and written by Alexandra Cunningham, and stars [[Connie Britton]] and [[Eric Bana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/dirty-john-connie-britton-eric-bana-point-of-view-interview-tca-1202899927/|title=‘Dirty John’ Team Talks Expanding Perspective of Bravo Adaptation|first=Danielle|last=Turchiano|date=8 August 2018|website=variety.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/eric-bana-dirty-john-bravo-connie-britton-1202742688/|title=Eric Bana to Star Opposite Connie Britton in Bravo Anthology Series ‘Dirty John’|first=Joe|last=Otterson|date=3 April 2018|website=variety.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/10/dirty-john-bravo-unveils-new-trailer-premiere-date-1202478642/|title=‘Dirty John’: Bravo Unveils New Trailer & Premiere Date|first=Denise|last=Petski|date=8 October 2018|website=deadline.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/bravos-dirty-john-true-crime-series-wants-cast-a-spell-viewers-1133270|title=Bravo's 'Dirty John' True-Crime Series Wants to Cast a Spell on Viewers|author=|date=|website=hollywoodreporter.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.marieclaire.com.au/dirty-john-tv-show-eric-bana-connie-britton|title=Eric Bana scares as John Meehan in Dirty John trailer|author=|date=|website=marieclaire.com.au|accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-et-st-dirty-john-bravo-tca-20180808-story.html|title=You liked the stories and podcast. '''Dramatic monologue''', also known as a [[persona]] poem, is a type of poetry written in the form of a speech of an individual character. [[M.H. Abrams]] notes the following three features of the ''dramatic monologue'' as it applies to poetry: {{Quotation| # A single person, who is patently ''not'' the poet, utters the speech that makes up the whole of the poem, in a specific situation at a critical moment […]. # This person addresses and interacts with one or more other people; but we know of the auditors' presence, and what they say and do, only from clues in the discourse of the single speaker. # The main principle controlling the poet's choice and formulation of what the lyric speaker says is to reveal to the reader, in a way that enhances its interest, the speaker's temperament and character.<ref>M. H. Abrams, gen. ed. "Dramatic Monologue." ''A Glossary of Literary Terms.'' 8th ed. Boston: Thomson Wadsworth, 2005. 70-71.</ref>}}
==Types of dramatic monologue==
One of the most important influences on the development of the dramatic monologue is [[romantic poetry]]. However, the long, personal lyrics typical of the Romantic period are not dramatic monologues, in the sense that they do not, for the most part, imply a concentrated narrative. Poems such as [[William Wordsworth]]'s ''[[Tintern Abbey (poem)|Tintern Abbey]]'' and [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]]'s ''[[Mont Blanc (poem)|Mont Blanc]]'', to name two famous examples, offered a model of close psychological observation and philosophical or pseudo-philosophical inquiry described in a specific setting. The [[conversation poems]] of [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]] are perhaps a better precedent. The genre was also developed by [[Felicia Hemans]] and [[Letitia Elizabeth Landon]], beginning in the latter's case with her long poem ''The Improvisatrice''.<ref>Serena Baiesi. ''Letitia Elizabeth Landon and Metrical Romance'', 2009, p.56-58.</ref>
The novel and plays have also been important influences on the dramatic monologue, particularly as a means of characterization. Dramatic monologues are a way of expressing the views of a character and offering the audience greater insight into that character's feelings. Dramatic monologues can also be used in novels to tell stories, as in [[Mary Shelley]]'s ''[[Frankenstein]]'', and to implicate the audience in moral judgments, as in [[Albert Camus]] ''[[The Fall (Albert Camus novel)|The Fall]]'' and [[Mohsin Hamid]]'s ''[[The Reluctant Fundamentalist]]''.
== Examples ==
The [[Victorian era|Victorian]] period represented the high point of the dramatic monologue in English poetry.
*[[Alfred, Lord Tennyson]]'s ''[[Ulysses (poem)|Ulysses]]'', published in 1842, has been called the first true dramatic monologue. After ''Ulysses'', Tennyson's most famous efforts in this vein are ''Tithonus'', ''The Lotos-Eaters,'' and ''St. Simon Stylites,'' all from the 1842 ''[[Poems (Tennyson, 1842)|Poems]]''; later monologues appear in other volumes, notably ''[[Idylls of the King]]''. *[[Matthew Arnold]]'s ''[[Dover Beach]]'' and ''Stanzas from the Grand Chartreuse'' are famous, semi-autobiographical monologues. The former, usually regarded as the supreme expression of the growing [[scepticism (philosophy)|scepticism]] of the mid-Victorian period, was published along with the latter in 1867's ''New Poems.'' *[[Robert Browning]] produced his most famous work in this form. While ''[[My Last Duchess]]'' is the most famous of his monologues, the form dominated his writing career. ''[[The Ring and the Book]]'', ''[[Fra Lippo Lippi (poem)|Fra Lippo Lippi]]'', ''[[Caliban upon Setebos]]'', ''[[Soliloquy of the Spanish Cloister]]'' and ''[[Porphyria's Lover]]'', as well as the other poems in ''[[Men and Women (poetry collection)|Men and Women]]'' are just a handful of Browning's monologues.
Other Victorian poets also used the form. [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] wrote several, including ''Jenny'' and ''The Blessed Damozel''; [[Christina Rossetti]] wrote a number, including ''The Convent Threshold.'' [[Augusta Webster]]'s ''A Castaway,'' ''Circe'', and ''The Happiest Girl In The World'', [[Amy Levy]]'s ''Xantippe'' and ''A Minor Poet,'' and [[Felicia Hemans]]'s ''Arabella Stuart'' and ''Properzia Rossi'' are all exemplars of this technique. [[Algernon Charles Swinburne]]'s ''[[Hymn to Proserpine]]'' has been called a dramatic monologue vaguely reminiscent of Browning's work. Some American poets have also written poems in the genre- famous examples include [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s [[The Raven]] and [[Sylvia Plath]]'s [[Daddy (poem)|Daddy]].
Post-Victorian examples include [[William Butler Yeats]]'s ''The Gift of Harun al-Rashid'', [[Elizabeth Bishop]]'s ''Crusoe in England'', and [[T.S. Eliot]]'s ''[[The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock]]'' and ''[[Gerontion]]''.

[[File:Electrophone 1901.jpg|thumb|325px|right|Electrophone Company listening salon, located at its London headquarters in Pelican House on [[Gerrard Street, London]] (1903)<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433000014450;view=1up;seq=131 "Telephone London"] by Henry Thompson, in ''London Living: Vol. III, '' edited by [[George R. Sims]], 1903, page 115.</ref>]] The '''Electrophone''' was a distributed audio system, which operated in the [[United Kingdom]], primarily in London between 1895 and 1925. Using conventional telephone lines, it relayed live [[theatre]] and [[music hall]] shows plus Sunday church services, to subscribers who listened over special headsets. It was ultimately unsuccessful in competing with the development of radio broadcasting in the early 1920s.
==History==
The Electrophone was preceded by the similarly organized [[Théâtrophone]] system of [[Paris, France]], which began operation in 1890. In 1894, Mr. H. S. J. Booth formed the Electrophone Company, Ltd. with an initial capitalization of £20,000,<ref>"The Pleasure Telephone" by [[Asa Briggs]], from ''The Social Impact of the Telephone'', Ithiel de Sola, Editor, 1997, page 41.</ref> and the service began operations in London the next year, with Booth acting as the Managing Director. Initially the company operated under a licence issued by the [[National Telephone Company]]. [[File:1917 London Electrophone hospital listeners.jpg|thumb|325px|right|Hospitalized British soldiers, joined by their toy elephant mascot (centre), enjoying the Electrophone service in The London Hospital (now The [[Royal London Hospital]]), probably Colton Ward, in late 1914<ref name="wounded">"British Wounded Hear London's Favorites Via Telephone", ''[[The Electrical Experimenter]]'', August 1917, page 230.</ref>]] To pick up the programmes, multiple large carbon microphones were placed in the theatre footlights to pick up the sounds of the performers. In churches, the microphones were disguised to look similar to bibles. Home subscribers were issued headphones connected to their standard telephone lines. The annual charge was £5, which limited its affordability to the well-to-do. [[Queen Victoria]] was included as one of the listeners.<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015080387452;view=1up;seq=166 "The Queen and the Electrophone"], ''[[The Electrician]]'', 26 May 1899, page 144.</ref> In 1897, it was noted that coin operated receivers had been installed in some hotels, which provided a few minutes of entertainment for a [[Sixpence_(British_coin)|sixpence]].<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015080386348;view=1up;seq=355 "The Electrophone"] by J. Wright, ''The Electrical Engineer'', 10 September 1897, page 344.</ref> Additional lines were installed, for free, for use by convalescing hospital patients.<ref name="wounded" />
A special manual switchboard, located at the Electrophone building in Pelican House on [[Gerrard Street, London]], provided links to the participating entertainment establishments and churches. Subscribers called Electrophone operators to have their lines connected to the site they selected. Subscribers with two telephone lines could use the second line to make a request to change the site during the course of an evening. A 1906 advertisement stated that they could choose from among fourteen theatres — the [[Aldwych Theatre|Aldwych]], [[Alhambra Theatre|Alhambra]], [[Apollo Theatre|Apollo]], [[Daly's Theatre|Daly's]], [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane]], [[Empire, Leicester Square|Empire]], [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety]], [[Lyric Theatre, London|Lyric]], [[Palace Theatre, London|Palace]], [[London Pavilion|Pavilion]], [[Prince of Wales's Theatre|Prince of Wales's]], [[Savoy Theatre|Savoy]], [[Shaftesbury Theatre|Shaftesbury]] and [[Tivoli Theatre of Varieties|Tivoli]] — in addition to concerts from the [[Queen's Hall|Queen's]] and [[Royal Albert Hall]]s, and, on Sundays, services from fifteen churches. <ref name="cable">[https://books.google.com/books?id=_n1vr0_RbXoC&pg=PA794&lpg=PA794&source=bl&ots=KwMu3TFuVh&sig=k021sfvDPF26PQY-1v3mtHC1fh4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKlpfoi4fNAhVCMFIKHaqjCHQQ6AEISzAM#v=onepage&q&f=false "Cable Radio — Victorian Style"] by Denys Parsons, ''[[New Scientist]]'', 30 December 1982, page 794.</ref>
In 1912, telephone operations were transferred to the control of the [[General Post Office]]. The Electrophone paid to the [[Postmaster General of the United Kingdom|Postmaster General]] an annual fee of £25 plus a royalty of [[Half crown (British coin)|half a crown]] per subscriber. In 1920, the service received £11,868 from subscribers, with operating expenses of £5866, including a £496 royalty payment to the Post Office. Theatres were paid 10 [[shilling (British coin)|shilling]]s annually for each connected subscriber.<ref>Parsons (1982), pages 795-796.</ref>
Although fairly long-lived, the Electrophone never advanced beyond a limited audience. In 1896 there were just 50 subscribers, although this increased to over 1000 by 1919, and just over 2000 at its peak in 1923. However, competition due to the introduction of radio broadcasting resulted in a rapid decline, falling to 1000 by November 1924. In early 1923 an Electrophone director was quoted as saying that "it would be a long time before broadcasting by wireless of entertainments and church services attained the degree of perfection now achieved by the electrophone."<ref>"Entertainment by Wireless: The Future of the Electrophone", ''[[The Times]]'', 10 January 1923, page 8.</ref> However, that proved to be overly optimistic, and as of June 30, 1925, the London Electrophone ceased operations.<ref>"Electrophone, Ltd.", ''The Times'', 17 June 1925, page 18.</ref> Note the use of the word "wireless" to refer to radio transmission, as opposed to the "hard wired" transmission of the Electrophone.
A second, much smaller system, was established in Bournemouth in 1903, but the maximum number of subscribers only reached 62 as of 1924. This system was finally discontinued in 1938, after it was determined during the previous year that there were only two remaining subscribers.<ref>Parsons (1982), page 796.</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} A '''film producer''' is a person who oversees the production of a film.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.producersguild.org/?page=faq|title=Frequently Asked Questions - Producers Guild of America|website=www.producersguild.org|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref> Either employed by a [[production company]] or working [[Independent film|independently]], producers plan and coordinate various aspects of film production, such as selecting the script; coordinating writing, directing, and editing; and arranging financing.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |url = http://lfs.org.uk/full-time-study/ma-filmmaking/areas-study/producing|title=Producing |publisher= London Film School|website= lfs.org.uk |language =en|access-date=}}</ref>
During the "discovery stage," the producer finds and selects promising material for development.<ref name=":1"/> Then, unless the film is based on an existing script, the producer has to hire a [[screenwriter]] and oversee the [[Filmmaking#Development|development of the script]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onetonline.org/link/summary/27-2012.01|title=27-2012.01 - Producers|website=www.onetonline.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref> Once a script is completed, the producer will lead a [[Pitch (filmmaking)|pitch]] to secure the financial backing (a "[[Green-light|green light]]") to allow production to begin.
The producer also supervises the pre-production, production, and post-production stages of filmmaking. One of the most important tasks is to hire the [[Film director|director]] and other key crew members. Whereas the director makes the creative decisions during the production, the producer typically manages the logistics and business operations, though some directors also produce their own films. The producer is tasked with making sure the film is delivered on time and within budget,<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=https://nationalcareersservice.direct.gov.uk/job-profiles/tv-or-film-producer#|title=TV or film producer|website=nationalcareersservice.direct.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-02-18}}</ref> and has the final say on creative decisions. Finally, the producer will oversee the marketing and [[Film distribution|distribution]].
For various reasons, producers cannot always supervise all of the production. In this case, the main producer may hire and delegate work to [[executive producer]]s, [[line producer]]s, or [[unit production manager]]s.<ref name="nyt22">{{cite news|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/08/three-studios-agree-to-plan-to-certify-who-deserves-to-be-a-producer/|title=Three Studios Agree to Let a Guild Certify Credits for Film Producers|last=Cieply|first=Michael|date=8 November 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> {{TOC limit|2}}
==Types== Different types of producers and their roles within the industry today include (in no order of seniority):
===Executive producer=== {{Main|Executive producer}} The executive producer oversees all of the other producers working on the same project. They make sure that the producers are fulfilling their roles on the given production. They can also be in charge of managing the film's finances and handling all other business aspects of the film.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">Zetti, Herbert (2011). ''Television Production Handbook 12th Edition''. Cengage Learning. p. 7. {{ISBN|978-1285052670}}</ref>
===Line producer=== {{Main|Line producer}} The line producer manages the staff and day-to-day operations and the oversees each and every physical aspect that is involved in the making of a film or television program. The line producer can be credited as "produced by" in certain cases.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
===Supervising producer=== The supervising producer supervises the creative process of screenplay development and often aids in script re-writes. They can also fulfill the executive producer's role of overseeing other producers.<ref name=":0" />
===Producer=== Within the production process, a producer can oversee, arrange, manage, and begin every single aspect. He or she is involved in every single stage of the overall production process.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
===Co-producer=== A co-producer is a member of a team of producers that perform all of the functions and roles that a single producer would have in a single given project.<ref name=":0" />
===Coordinating producer or production coordinator=== {{Main|Production coordinator}} A coordinating producer coordinates the work/role of multiple producers who are trying to achieve a shared result.<ref name=":0" />
===Associate producer or assistant producer=== The associate or assistant producer helps the producer during the production process. He/she can sometimes be involved in coordinating others' jobs, such as creating peoples' schedules and hiring the main talent.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
===Segment producer=== A segment producer produces one or more single specific segments of a multi-segment film or television production.<ref name=":0" />
===Field Producer=== A field producer helps the producer by overseeing all of the production that takes place outside of the studio in specific locations for the film.<ref name=":2" />
==Responsibilities== ===Development (film rights)=== During this stage of the production process, producers bring together people like the [[film director]], [[cinematographer]], and [[production designer]].<ref name=":03">{{Cite web|url=http://creativeskillset.org/job_roles/757_producer|title=Producer|website=creativeskillset.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-18}}</ref> Unless the film is supposed to be based on an original script, the producer has to find an appropriate [[screenwriter]].<ref name="rottentomatoes.com2">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/casino_royale/news/1648610/007_writers_to_tackle_quotbarbarellaquot/|title=writers Neal Purvis and Robert Wade have been hired to pen the screenplay for producer Dino de Laurentiis|accessdate=13 April 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmmakers.com/artists/williamgoldman/biography/page2.htm|title=Goldman was contacted by director/producer Rob Reiner to write the screenplay|accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref> If an existing script is considered flawed, they are able to order a new version or make the decision to hire a [[script doctor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidlynch.de/dunetimeout.html|title=He began work on the script. And worked on it and worked on it, pushing it through seven drafts before arriving at a version with which de Laurentiis was satisfied|accessdate=11 November 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121133818/http://davidlynch.de/dunetimeout.html|archive-date=21 November 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/thespy.htm|title=Broccoli insisted on a rewrite, claiming to the story was too political for a 007 film. Writer Christopher Wood was brought on board to collaborate with Maibaum and expand upon Broccoli's personal concept for the film|accessdate=14 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510193135/http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/thespy.htm|archivedate=10 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/aug/04/tom-mankiewicz-obituary|title=the producers Albert R Broccoli and Harry Saltzman hired him for two weeks to doctor the Richard Maibaum script of Diamonds Are Forever|last=Bergan|first=Ronald|date=4 August 2010|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=4 August 2010}}</ref> The producer also has the final say on which [[film director]], cast members, or other staff get hired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/79836%7C0/War-and-Peace.html|title=Next De Laurentiis hired King Vidor, director of Duel in the Sun (1946) and The Fountainhead (1949) to make the movie|accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/film-obituaries/8127250/Dino-De-Laurentiis.html|title=Dino De Laurentiis [obituary]|quote =He also stuck loyally by gifted American directors when they were out of favour or off form. Robert Altman made one of his less successful pictures, Buffalo Bill and the Indians (1976), for De Laurentiis, who also helped the luckless Michael Cimino back on his feet after the commercial disaster of Heaven's Gate|date=11 November 2010|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|accessdate=}}</ref> In some cases, they also have the last word when it comes to casting questions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/octopus.htm|title=Octopussy|quote =Cubby Broccoli personally broke his own golden rule and cast her as the mysterious Octopussy|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510170037/http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/octopus.htm|archivedate=10 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A producer's role will also consist of approving locations, the studio hire, the final [[shooting script]], the [[production schedule]], and the budget. More time and money spent in pre-production can reduce the time and money wasted during production time.<ref name=":03"/>
===Pre-production=== During production, the producer's job is to make sure the film stays on schedule and under budget.<ref name=":14"/> They will always be in contact with directors and other key creative team members.<ref name=":03"/><ref name = bergan>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/jan/30/bernd-eichinger-obituary|title=Bernd Eichinger [obituary]|quote =In 1979, Eichinger bought a large stake in the Munich-based production and distribution company Constantin Film, which he ran as a hands-on producer for over 30 years|last=Bergan|first=Ronald|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name = europacorp>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/the-movie-business-luc-besson-s-growing-empire-a-612371.html|title=Europacorp studio posted $186 million in revenues last year, making it second only to Germany's Constantin Film as Europe's largest independent studio|accessdate=10 March 2009}}</ref> In addition to this, cast and [[film crew]] often work at different times or places, and certain films even require a [[second unit]]. The executive producer of the ''[[Star Wars]]'' original trilogy was [[George Lucas]] himself, the creator of the ''Star Wars'' universe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lucasfilm.com/inside/bio/georgelucas.html|title=Lucas continued the Star Wars saga as story writer and executive producer with The Empire Strikes Back in 1980 and Return of the Jedi in 1983.|accessdate=20 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040405085412/http://www.lucasfilm.com/inside/bio/georgelucas.html|archivedate=5 April 2004|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Production=== For various reasons, producers cannot always personally supervise all parts of their production. For example, some producers run a company which also deals with film distribution.<ref name = bergan/><ref name = europacorp/> Also, cast and [[film crew]] often work at different times and places, and certain films even require a [[second unit]].
===Post-production=== During post-production, the producer has the last word on whether sounds, music, or scenes have to be changed or cut. Even if the shooting has been finished, the producers can still demand that additional scenes be filmed. In the case of a negative [[test screening]], producers may even demand and get an alternative film ending. This happened, for example, with ''[[First Blood]].'' The test audience reacted very negatively when Rambo died, so the producers re-shot a new ending.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://davidmorrell.net/rambo-pages/david-morrell-on-rambo/|title=test audiences nearly rioted after cheering for Rambo and then seeing him die. So the producers went back to Hope, British Columbia, the location for the film, and shot a new ending in which Rambo lives|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> In addition to this, producers work with marketing and distribution companies in order to sell the film or arrange its distribution rights.<ref name=":14"/>
==The union== Within the industry, all of the producers union contracts are negotiated by [[Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers|The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP)]]. It was founded in 1924 by the U.S Trade Association as the Association of Motion Picture Producers.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url = http://collections.oscars.org/link/bio/1473|title = Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) records|website =Special Collections: Margaret Herrick Library |publisher = Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences}}</ref> It was originally created to only negotiate labor contracts, but during the mid-1930s they took over all contract negotiation responsibilities that were once controlled by the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]].<ref name=":4" /> This alliance negotiates with a wide range of other associations when dealing with producers union contracts. These associations include, the [[American Federation of Television and Radio Artists]] (AFTRA), the [[Directors Guild of America]] (DGA), and the [[Screen Actors Guild]] (SAG).<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://amptp.org/|title=AMPTP|website=amptp.org|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref> They negotiate over eighty industry wide union agreements and on behalf of 350 producers within the industry. It has been responsible for negotiating all of these union contracts within the industry since 1982. Today, it is considered the industry's official contract negotiation representative for everyone within the industry.<ref>[http://filmmakeriq.com/2012/09/a-guide-to-hollywood-unions/ "A Guide to Hollywood Unions | FilmmakerIQ.com"]. ''filmmakeriq.com''. Retrieved 2017-02-19.</ref>
==Career process== There are many different ways to become a film producer. [[Stanley Kramer]] started as an [[Film editing|editor]] and [[writer]], while other producers started as actors or directors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/collections/stanley-kramer-collection|title=Mr. Kramer began his career in the 1930s as an editor and writer, later forming an independent production company|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref>
However, most producers start in a college, university or film school. On the occasion of announcing his own film school, 'École de la Cité, film producer [[Luc Besson]] admitted that at the beginning of his career, he would have appreciated the chance to attend a film school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecoledelacite.com/en/|title=École de la cité|website=Ecole de la cité}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/luc-besson-launches-film-school-1118055818/|title=Luc Besson launches film school|work=Variety|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> [[Film school]]s and many [[University|universities]] offer [[Academic degree|degree courses]] that include film production knowledge, with some courses that are especially designed for future film producers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenacademyscotland.ac.uk/content-114|title=The MFA Advanced Film Practice programme aims to equip you with the creative, professional and technical knowledge you will need to enter the professional arena as a writer, producer or director.|accessdate=15 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416155055/http://www.screenacademyscotland.ac.uk/content-114|archivedate=16 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fondazionecsc.it/context.jsp?ID_LINK=18&area=7|title=The training course last three years and the interdisciplinary teaching programme prepares students in the specific areas of directing, scriptwriting, acting, photography, editing, sound techniques, production, set design, props and wardrobe|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> These courses focus on key topics like [[Pitch (filmmaking)|pitching]], [[script development]], script assessment, shooting schedule design, and budgeting.<ref name="Filmakademie2">{{cite web|url=https://www.filmakademie.de/en/studium/course-of-study/production/production/|title=Course of Study - Production |accessdate= |website = Filmakademie Baden Wurttemberg GmbH|language = en}}</ref><ref name=":1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westminster.ac.uk/about-us/schools/media/departments/photography|title=Our BA in Film Production is one of our most highly sought-after courses.|accessdate=15 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202000449/http://www.westminster.ac.uk/about-us/schools/media/departments/photography|archivedate=2 February 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dffb.de/html/en/studium/produktion|title=Producing seminars teach through practical studies in production, script development, budgeting, and media economics|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> Students can also expect practical training regarding post-production.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bfm.ee/programmes/film-arts/film-arts-ma/|title=All student films are developed, shot and post-produced in teams, closely mirroring a realistic industry work process in order to ease graduates' transitions to the professional environment|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> Training at a top producing school is one of the most efficient ways a student can show professionals they are not a rookie.<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nyfa.edu/student-resources/becoming-a-producer-tried-and-tested-career-paths/|title=Becoming a Producer - Tried and Tested Career Paths|date=2015-06-12|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en-US|newspaper=Student Resources}}</ref>
While education is one way to begin a career as a film producer, experience is also required to land a job. [[Internship]]s are a great way to gain experience while in school and give students a solid foundation on which to build their career. Many internships are paid, which enable students to earn money while gaining hands-on skills from industry professionals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thebalance.com/how-to-get-a-production-internship-1283507|title=Where to Look for Internship Programs in Entertainment|access-date=2017-02-03|newspaper=The Balance}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://creativeskillset.org/creative_industries/film/ways_into_the_industry|title=Ways into the film industry - Film Industry - Creative Skillset|website=creativeskillset.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> Through internships, students get to network with people in the film industry as well. This pays off in the end when looking for jobs after school. Once an internship is over, the next step typically will be to land a junior position, such as a [[production assistant]].<ref name=":22" />
Although rates can vary based on a producer's role and the location of filming, the average salary can start anywhere from $20,000 to $70,000, even doubling when working in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nyfa.edu/student-resources/jobs-film-average-salary-career-paths/|title=Jobs in Film: Average Salary & Career Paths|date=2014-12-01|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en-US|newspaper=Student Resources}}</ref> The average annual salary for a producer in the U.S. is $109,844. When examining more than 15,000 producers in the Los Angeles metropolitan area, the average annual salary is $138,640.<ref name="entertainment.howstuffworks.com2">{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/highest-paying-jobs-film-industry.htm#page=1|title=10 Highest Paying Jobs in the Film Industry|date=30 May 2008|publisher=}}</ref> Producers can also have an agreement to take a percentage of a movie's sales.<ref name="entertainment.howstuffworks.com2" />
There is no average work day for a film producer, since their tasks are changing from day to day. A producer's work hours are often irregular and can consist of very long days with the possibility of working nights and weekends.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prospects.ac.uk/job-profiles/television-film-video-producer|title=Television/film/video producer job profile {{!}} Prospects.ac.uk|website=www.prospects.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-02-20}}</ref>
